text: There was a lot of commotion around his election probabilities, and a lot of noise from the dude such as "I ran 80,000 simulations and Kamala won in 50.1% of them, the odds are really as close as you can get!". text: I have literally hundreds of books in my pile, mostly electronic - I only get hard copies of stuff I can't get electronically or I really want sitting around in my eyeline. Some of them related to fundamentals of the sports I'm interested in, some around the recent rise in sports analytics (I was asked to contribute to one on football, declined, and glad that I did, as that field has now _rapidly_ outpaced what I could offer back then, never mind now), quite a few on trading in general (forgot about Lefevre, read that in the early 2000s - fun book, not very useful), and of course the usual sports trading go-tos. I tend to speed read and select pieces out of each to dive into further that I think might be more useful. In 2025 I'm expecting to go back to some maths stuff: fundamentals of stats, regression, etc. and core data science pieces which I hope will inspire pieces for the blog (shut up, I know).

text:
OK here goes. After a bit of rare civil discourse with the Betdaq guy on Twitter the chat turned to courtsiders and inplay delays. This made me start thinking about the synchronicity of delays across exchanges on the same markets. I know that football delays vary considerably from region to region and I was wondering if

a) Would a variation in inplay delay across exchanges lead to something exploitable or make one market more efficient than the other?
b) Do exchanges communicate with each other in this regard to ensure that they are all applying the same inplay delay for each market type.

I'm working on the (possibly misguided) theory that once the passive bet delay goes to zero (assuming it happens) will we be looking at more efficient markets in general???

elements.text:
OK here goes. After a bit of rare civil discourse with the Betdaq guy on Twitter the chat turned to courtsiders and inplay delays. This made me start thinking about the synchronicity of delays across exchanges on the same markets. I know that football delays vary considerably from region to region and I was wondering if

a) Would a variation in inplay delay across exchanges lead to something exploitable or make one market more efficient than the other?
b) Do exchanges communicate with each other in this regard to ensure that they are all applying the same inplay delay for each market type.

I'm working on the (possibly misguided) theory that once the passive bet delay goes to zero (assuming it happens) will we be looking at more efficient markets in general???

text: Sorry, I wasn't really talking about the zero passive delay. More thinking about how the delay (or difference in delay) across exchanges might lead to one being more efficient than the other - not so much for arbitrage but maybe to spot opportunity on the less efficient exchange. Say a theoretical example, football match has delays of 7 and 13 seconds respectively on 2 different exchanges - would either exchange be a) aware of the other's difference b) give a shit either way.

text:
Wow - that's quite a read. So basically BPE dosen't work on Betdaq (for reasons nefarious or otherwise). Saying that though, if BA is polling prices then there is always going to be irregularity between what people see and what actually is there. Surely you'd need a stream recording to actually prove that is happening?
Regardless, that shits all over my intention to start putting money through betdaq any time soon.

text:
I recently got my betdaq reactivated and API usage granted. I was sent some truly shocking documentation - not just the SOAP API but there was also something with JSON which looked like a rudimentary sort of stream (all very amateurish with shocking docs). I implemented some of the SOAP stuff with the view of just throwing some simple strats in those markets to test the water. But people sitting at a ladder on variable refresh rates , possibly using polling updates are surely going to miss some price changes? That said, no excuse for Betdaq to not be able to either find an error or produce the paper trail evidence for why those bets were matched without BPE as it appears.
Either way think I will steer clear until they update that thread with a satisfactory explanation.

elements.text:
I recently got my betdaq reactivated and API usage granted. I was sent some truly shocking documentation - not just the SOAP API but there was also something with JSON which looked like a rudimentary sort of stream (all very amateurish with shocking docs). I implemented some of the SOAP stuff with the view of just throwing some simple strats in those markets to test the water. But people sitting at a ladder on variable refresh rates , possibly using polling updates are surely going to miss some price changes? That said, no excuse for Betdaq to not be able to either find an error or produce the paper trail evidence for why those bets were matched without BPE as it appears.
Either way think I will steer clear until they update that thread with a satisfactory explanation.

Today OpenAI announced o3, its next-gen reasoning model. We've worked with OpenAI to test it on ARC-AGI, and we believe it represents a significant breakthrough in getting AI to adapt to novel tasks.

It scores 75.7% on the semi-private eval in low-compute mode (for $20 per task

text:
I haven't scraped bookies in recent years, but it was often easier to look at mobile/app/lightweight versions of the websites, e.g. <https://mobile.bet365.com|https://mobile.bet365.com>. Spoofing a 'dumb' or older user agent often helped as it changed the content format. Also worth considering none-uk versions of the site.
As a general question, how delayed are aggregation sites like oddschecker, etc?

elements.text: I haven't scraped bookies in recent years, but it was often easier to look at mobile/app/lightweight versions of the websites, e.g.
https://mobile.bet365.com

. Spoofing a 'dumb' or older user agent often helped as it changed the content format. Also worth considering none-uk versions of the site.
As a general question, how delayed are aggregation sites like oddschecker, etc?

text:
I work _a lot_ with GenAI models. It's been my life for 18 months now. I can't talk about a lot of what we do, but it's cutting edge (we were doing RAG and GraphRAG within weeks of respective papers being published), and I get to work with applied and research scientists with PhDs in this space, trying to push the envelope, many of whom are getting papers selected for major confs and journals.

My 2p: I doubt this has applicability to this domain right now. It's getting there, directionally this is promising, but the fact you're going to need 2 orders of magnitude more money to go from 75.7% to 87.5%, and that higher number is still basically useless for a lot of things you can do for a lot less money with humans means I'd hold back on the excitement for now.

with GenAI models. It's been my life for 18 months now. My 2p: I doubt this has applicability to this domain right now. It's getting there, directionally this is promising, but the fact you're going to need 2 orders of magnitude more money to go from 75.7% to 87.5%, and that higher number is still basically useless for a lot of things you can do for a lot less money with humans means I'd hold back on the excitement for now.

text: I ~know~ strongly suspect that they're over-fitting a bit to ARC-AGI and AIME style problems. The coding capabilities are trained on competitive programming problems which aren't really like real world problems you and I care about.

elements.text: I
know

strongly suspect that they're over-fitting a bit to ARC-AGI and AIME style problems. The coding capabilities are trained on competitive programming problems which aren't really like real world problems you and I care about.

text: And the costs... oh my, this is so expensive, even if you get cheap hardware and run it in a cheap part of the World (think crypto-farm hotspots like Mongolia with cheap coal/electricity and reduced cooling needs), you're paying $100k-$1m/hour for workloads you could pay humans in North American & Europe who charge $50/hour to do.

text: But yeah, the results look like a step change.

elements.text: But yeah, the results look like a step change.
